pageContext.desc: Written from the Oklahoma Territory, the Southwest, and the Dakotas, regarding his commissioned series of portraits of prominent Indian Chiefs.
pageContext.category: Edward E. Ayer Manuscript Collection; Indians of North America; Letters (Correspondence)

pages.transcription:
sincere for a happy birthday.
As usual, I haven't any news. I went to the Show twice last week. Friday there was a double feature and both of them were murder pictures and altho the acting was good, I much prefer romances. They lasted from 1:30 to 5:00, much too long. and I had to leave to get the bus.
Frances was out to see me a week ago and she looked fine. She has been working very hard.
Received your letters and cards and enjoyed them. Are you 89 or 90 - just imagine andstill having sweeties
N.

Sunday Morning
August 18, 1946
My Dear Elbridge,
I am returning the letters and cards that you sent for me to read.
We are having a much needed rain today. We had a very good rain Friday night, but not enough to do much good. The crops and gardens were suffering for rain. As it was raining when it was time to start to Sunday School, I did not go.
A cousin just called and ask me to her house to dinner today. A cousin of ours from Virginia is visiting in Elkins. She is invited to dinner too.
I am so glad that you and Peggy had a good dinner on your birthday. You certainly will miss her if she goes away from San Francisco to work. It would be so nice for you
if she could get work there.

Thank you for the coin. I have never seen one like it. Really I don't know very much about money. I never have American money long enough to get well acquainted with it. Ha!
I do have a Lincoln head penny collection to date. You know that the first Lincoln pennies were made in 1909. I have one of each date since 1909 to 1946.
Last evening a girl friend and I went to see the movie Smoky the Cow Horse. The scenery in it was lovely. There wasn't a lot to the plot, but the horse in it was good.
It is time to get ready for the dinner.
Lots of love,
Davie

"Hello" Pal
So nice it couldn't be nicer
That's how your day should be - 
'Cause honest, all the year around
That's how you seem to me.
Happy Birthday
Saturday
and many more
Gladys Illagee
1946
little boy in costume, donkey with cactus--image

Tuesday Morning
August 20, 1946
My Dear Elbridge,
I am sending you a money
order for the amount I still owe
you for pictures and cards.
3 Indian houses             $3.00
20 Lincoln profile cards  $1.00

                         Total   $4.00

Will you please check
and see if this is correct?
Did I send you the money
for the cat post cards? I am
not sure. I will appreciate
it very much if you will
check and send me a statement
of what I still owe you, if I
owe more.
The "Loan Me A Dollar" card
is very clever, but I cannot
afford to buy any more now. I just won’t be able to buy
(unreadable due to fold in paper) until I get my
first check the last of September.

Thank-you so much for the fine cards you sent me. I liked them.
Now, I must get to work. I have to go up town and see to a lot of things today.
Lots of love,
Davie

Dear Cousin Elbridge,
Thank you for the cards. Especially the comical cats a fine duet!
I haven't painted a single new sketch, as with my dear brother Robert here. I leave no time to spare, as there is much house cleaning, cooking, and DISHES. 
& attempts to trim trees and fight against Dirt! That's one reason marriage never had any attractions for me. The skies & trees have been my

first and last loves! Country people cannot understand that attitude - but I seem so contented. They think I'm a bit lonely! Well, perhaps all artists are! I'm almost weeping because my h. doesn't want to keep our antiques! Many people love them. I often love to feel the surface of fine mahogany - Well I'll love to have a sale aft? 2 months before I die & use boxes for chairs & beds a give a legacy to my family in COLD CASH. Never let them
Kum!? 
yours affectionately,
Cunclear Amy L. Burbank

September 4, 1946
E.A. Burbank
Manx Hotel
San Francisco
Dear Sir,
Please accept the thanks of the library for the gift of the portrait of Abraham Lincoln. We are glad to have this autographed copy for our library.
Very truly yours
Georgiana Lunt
Librarian

better not be too good or someone with a spare maid's room will offer her a job from the audience.
Speaking of jobs - I am tactfully (i.e. - not using a sledge hammer too obviously) negotiating a job on the Pony Express since I have done newspaper work and a great deal of musical and early California research - that and a photographic memory which mom finds disconcerting when it comes to her age.
We are not coming to the city until the other wisdom teeth are out and Daddy gives us the go-ahead signal for another shopping spree.Then we shall come to see you - my mother's nice - you'll like her - doesn't look old enough to be related to me though - 
Hope you are feeling well - Sincerely
Norma Angini

is the way that you feel also. Nothing scintillating has happened rately in the spriortly town of sm - folds up the sidewalks at nine on the dot. Last night four of us painted San Francisco a rather pale red color. We had dinner at a wonderful place out in North Black. some dough French bread, ravioli, etc. Someone said there were seven ourses but I can only count six. No wonder those Italians have an excess of avoir ... (Incidentally - in case you wondered about my name - we are French Swiss - londess 
and no relation to the late Mussolini - did get a lot of suspicious looks during the war though.)
Anyhoo we all ambled down to the St-Francis where I was politely requested to leave the bar bring two months short of twenty-one and a coke drink. My date hit the woy - so we went right around the corner to the ... room Had waiters like to be so smug and classify us as a drinking generation going straight to the dogs.
The Peninsula Symphony is ...nicely and has recently sponsored someone to pay the bills. Bills for what. We don't know. Who knows. someday we may even give a concert of some of those monstrosities we practice so diligently.
One of my girl friends is still down at Stanford and appearing in « School For Scandal » that they are doing this weekend. They really put on some good things there with their students casts although Roberta is only a maid in this play. She had

Sunday-
Dear Mr. Burbank-
Thank you so much for your letter and especially for the drawing of Lincoln which I had admired so much over at the Hamlins. I am putting it away in my hope chest now with some French prints but will frame it later on to put in a study – if a man ever comes over the horizon with enough money for a study. We had quite a rabid discussion the other night about the virtues of Lincoln is. Washington and I’m afraid that George come out on the

Friday Night
August 23, 1946
Dear Elbridge,
Your letters, cards, books magazines, and clippings have been coming right along, and I love them. You are the grandest friend that I have ever had. I actually miss it when there isn't some kind of mail from you every day. Honest I don't see how you have time to write me so often.
Thank you for everything. Everyone that sees the cat card and "Can you loan me a dollar" card like them. They all take a good laugh. I think that they are very clever. I really
laugh every time I look at them, especially the cats. The books are interesting, I like the one about American Women best. Thank you for sending them.
This is an especially good,

page-2
and colorful number of the Arizona Highways. I like the ones that have a lot of colored pictures in them, don't you? You are such a good, generous person to share your magazine with me. It isn't any wonder that your friends love you so much.
I have not heard from Mrs. Shore for weeks, but I was talking to her sister this week. She said that Mrs. Shore had been very busy. I believe that she has been
managing the hotel where they stay while the manager is on vacation. I hope that I will have a letter from her soon.
Did you like the maple sugar that I sent you for your birthday? Daddy boiled the sugar water into syrup on the farm then we unclear unclear unclear

Page - 3
Bessie is at Camp Campbell
in Kentucky. She is going to
stay in the army for awhile
longer. She likes it very much.
Hers feet are getting much better.
I just had a letter from her
today. She had had a poss
and gone to Chicago for three
days. She said that she had
had a good time.
Yes, I have been in the
Smithsorian Institute twice, but
one could spend unclear there
and newer? see all that there
is to see.
I do hope by? this time
that you have gotten the
money from Mr. Backofen. It
isn't like a collector of Lincolniane?
to he so slow about paying
his honest delits?. I have
not heard from him for
such a long time
Tonight is almost cold
enough for frost. In fact 
a fire unclear feel unclear

Page 4
The home been having quite a lot of company these days. August always seems to lie the month when our relationel come visiting. That is a good time for now we can get things from the farm to eat. Food is so high to buy that we just couldn't afford to buy things from the store. Just one more week and school will begin. It doesn't seem possible that the summer has gone so quickly. I am rather anxious for school to begin as I need the money. It is late and I am cold. A good wool blanket is going to feel good tonight.
Lots of love for you.
Always.
Danie

Friday Morning
August 30, 1946
My Dear Elbridge,
This has been such a busy
week. It sems that all of 
our friends and relatives take
their vacations in August. I
just havn't found time for 
getting my clothes ready for
schoal let alone get any letters
written.
The envelope that you
returned that was received
of Saw Franciso with the
contents gone contained the
letters that you had sent me
to read. I just put them are
in the envelope with a little 
note from me. My, I hope
that none of them were
inportant. That envelope
looks to me like someone had
deliberably torn in open. I am
glad that they did not get
the one with the money order
in it. That was what I was

afraid had happened when I opened your letter, and saw the torn envelope. 
I sent your money order to $4.00 one day, and the next day your letter came saying that I sill owed you $3.00. Do you have everything straight now? Please don't hesitate to Tell me if I let things slip by. I am glad to be reminded. 
Thank you for all the clipping, cards, and magazines, you are so good to me. 
The bod with the colored pebbles in it came. They are pretty. Had you sent the things for the Marine Garden? I do not have one. 
School opens next week. In a way I will be very glad. We are having quite a shortage of the teachers hear too. I don't know what we are going to do. You first can't blame

Page 3
They get such low wages, and the cast of living has grace up so high. Teachers first have to live too.
It is very cold here today. Cold enough for the people to wear coats. 
Do you remember Gene Kathloway, the soldier, who wrote you a letter once? He was in Elkins last week, and came to see me. I showed him several of the pictures that you have given to me. He likes all of the them. I gave him the one of the car cards and of the " Can You Loan Me A Dollar". he liked both of them, especially the cars as he is very fond of cats. 
This isn't an answer to our grand letters that have been coming every day, but just a short one to tell you that I think of you everyday, and that I will write

Page 4
as often and I can/ you are such a grand person to go right and writing when I have so little time to write to you. I just don't think that there is anyone else in all the world who would be so good as you are. 
i am looking forward to the red drawing that it will be be good. I am also helping that Mr. Hamlin will use the pictre of your soon for The Pony Express that Mr. Buell made of you. I am quite anxious to see it. 
I must get ready to go up town as I have several things to do. 
With love,

Davie

Sunday Night
September 1, 1946
My Dear Eldridge, 
The red drawing of the Indian girl came. It was grand! I like it so much. Are you just giving it me? Thank you so much. I will frame it in a brown frame as you said. Prudgie likes it very much too. 
Monday Eve
I was just too tired and sleepy to finish this letter last night, but will add a little more now. 
School opens tomorrow, and we will have a teacher's meeting at 7:00 tonight. It is now 5:00. I'm writing this while supper cooks. Prudgie is working on a jacket for me. it is the jacket to a suit that I ordered last year, and it has always been too large.

Will you please autograph the two enclosed Lincoln cards for my friend Fern Nance Pond.  She collects autographs and Lincoln items too.  She would like to have your autograph for her collection.  You may write something on the cards too if you like.  I will send the cards to her.  I will appreciate it very much if you do this for me.  Mrs. Pond is a good friend of mine, and such a grand women.  You would like her very much.  She is the one mentioned in the clipping that Mrs. Shore showed you.  The "O" in my name is for Olga.  I think that is very pretty but I seldom use only the "O."  We have been having very cold days here.  We have had

a fire almost every day for the past three weeks. Today is a little warmer. I feel that September May be warmer. That makes it hard for the kiddies starting back to school after a long vacation.
Thank you very much for the pictures and postcards. The ones of the Indian girls are very interesting. I can imagine that their costumes are very colorful.
I really had to laugh at the card of the colored kiddies.
I do hope that you have heard from Mr. [Backafen?] and he has paid you. One would think that an army officer would be more prompt with his payments. I just never dreamed that he would be like that when I gave him your address. You see

I sent him one of your Lincoln cards and he liked it, and wanted your address. That is how I came to send it to him. I hope that he has sent you the money by now. I will write him again and remind him that he owes you the money.
Andy, Pudgie’s boy, said, “Aunt Davie, what are doing?”, and I said , “Aunt Davie is writing a letter to Mr. Burbank.” He knows that I hear from you so often, and he thinks every time I write that I am writing to you. Ha!
I must get ready for the meeting now. Will write more later.
Lots of love,
Davie
P.S. Thank you again for the fine driving of the Indian girl.

Wednesday Night
September 5, 1946
Dear Eldridge,
It just doesn’t look like I will ever get caught up with your letters, but I will try.
School opened yesterday, and so far things have been very pleasant. I hope they will continue so. My, but I have been tired each evening. It looks as if I will have to get used to school again.
I had a letter from my friend Mrs. Shore. She told me that she had been to visit you. I hope that she will call again soon.
I wrote Mr. [Backafen?] a letter tonight, and told him that you had not gotten the money for the Lincoln pictures. I hope he will send it now.
Thank you for the Mechanix Illustrated. It is very interesting.

The hobo poem was very amusing. They really have some clever things in their magazine.
Thank you very much for Their New Masters card. I have some of these on hand. I just can’t afford to buy anything till I get my first month pay.
The card with the yellow roses is lovely! Thank you for it. You have sent me so many lovely card lately
The clippings on the cities of the dead are most interesting, I think.
The card of Telegraph Hill is a very interesting one. It must have been a very hard picture to draw. I do like it.
I like the Saturday Evening Post very much. I buy it at the news stands once in a while.

Mr. Backafen he was waiting in a store. I have never met him.
Yes, I got The Sunset magazine, and I enjoyed it. That was the first time I ever saw a copy or new that they put out a magazine by that name.
I hope that Mr. Hamlin will use the Horace Greeley picture the one of you for the Pony Express soon.  I am anxious to see them.
Maybe in a few days I will get rested, and feel like writing you a longer letter. Just remember that I think of you always.
Lots of love,
Davie

prominent  place in the store which is now owned by Bob Karagan.  A few years ago while visiting Roman Hubbel’s home in Gallup, I saw many of your lovely paintings. 
We are contemplating building a High School just as soon as we can get the materials.
How is your health? I hope that you are very well and that God will bless you with an abundance of his blessings
Sincerely yours,
Sister M. Honora

Sisters of the Blessed Sacrament St Michael's Indian School St Michaels, Arizona
August 18, 1946
Dear Mr Burbank,
We received your cute little picture of Me...Harry?? Many thanks.
I am just wondering if you know how few of your old friends are left at St Michaels. Most of them have done to their heavenly reward. At present as far as I can remember Father Birand? and my self are the only ones left in this part of the country. Joe Kuhn? is in Los Angeles, but his picture which you painted of him in his store still occupies a

Sunday Afternoon September 8, 1946
Mr Dear Elbridge
Yesterday brought four letters from you. Two contained only clippings, but they were interesting. I enjoyed, especially, the poems that you sent. They were good. 
Yes, I wrote Mr Backofew?, but have not heard from him. I do hope that he has sent you the money by this time. I'm really sorry that I sent him your Lincoln cards now. 
If I were you, I would not do any more painting for people you do not know in advance without pay in advance. At least I would ask them for a down payment.
Our schools did not open until the day after Labor Day. I spent Labor Day at home working. In the evening I went

Page 2
to a teacher's meeting.
Cactus plants do not grow wild in West Virginia. Many people have them for house plants. We? have two kinds - one is called a Christmas cactus , and the other one has lovely large blooms on it. I like them for house plants as they do not require so much care as many other house plants.
Thank you so much for the fine Lincoln clippings.
No, I did not see anything amusing about the "embalming clipping".
Some of the Barnaby cartoons are very clever, and as you say some are not.
The inclosed picture of me was taken at the Lincoln Home in Springfield. This is the only home Mr. Lincoln every owned.
This is a grand day. I seem to be the only person

Page 3.
staying at home. I went to Sunday School and church this morning. So I thought that I would stay at home and try to catch up on my letter writing. It would seem that I never do get caught up.
Did you see Mr Burton Holmes while he was in San Francisco? I can imagine that his lectures are very good.
You probably have my letter now telling you that I received the red drawing of the Indian girl. It was bent, but I have it under some heavy books, and I hope that it will soon straighten out. I like it very much, as does Pudgie.
I have three sisters living, Rebecca, Opal, and Pudgie living, and two sisters dead unclear and Gwendoline.

4
Pudgie's twin is a boy, They do not look much alike. I have two brothers - Robert and Willard.
Have you seen any of Dick's paintings and drawings since he has been going to Art school? Has he improved a lot?
I do hope that Mr. Millett will send me one of his pictures. He wrote once that he would, but I have never heard any more from him. 
Later
My Uncle George and family just came by, and ask me to go for a drive so I went. I am so glad that I did for our hills are lovely. The leaves have turned as much now as they usually are in October.
You ask if I sing. I sing very little. Pudgie has a lovely voice unclear

Page 5
in the church choir. 
I have not seen my niece, Sharon, lately, but I will give her the cards when I do. I know that she will like them. She thinks that the cat picture is very clever. 
Sharon is quite a grown up little girl now. She will seventeen in January. This is her third year in high school.
I believe that I wrote to you that I liked the picture of telegraph Hill. That surely looks like a long flight of steps.
Yes, I think the story of Mike and his cow very good. I am going to use that on some of my friends. Ha!
On our drive this afternoon we stopped at Davis to eat dinner. My, we had a good dinner - baked chicken, mashed potatoes, peas, pineapple unlear

salad, and lemon pie. I just couldn't eat all of mine. The servings were too large. I just won't need any breakfast.
I had a letter from Mrs. Shore, and she told me about her visit with you. I wish that I could be there and could drop in to see you when you aren't busy. That would so nice. Maybe if something doesn't happen to prevent, and I can save some money, I can come out there next summer and see you.
Now I must get to some other letters.
Lots of love, 
Daisie?

Tuesday
My dear EAB Guess I am in the dog house. I forgot about the holiday and Saturday I realized my mailman wouldn't be here until to-day so there was no use waiting until to-day. As I wrote you, I had my glasses changed and although I am feeling much better and don't want to doze? most? of the time. There is a place? in my right glass that annoyed me just like

a new plate? hurts your guns?.I went back but he seemed to think it was O.K. but I am going in again to-day as it sure makes me nervous. I have worn bifocals since I was 40? also. He told me to get Murine? for an eye wash but that doesn't correct the glass. You have aileed? me a couple of times about a daughnul? card but I don't believe I ever saw one. I never hear a word about Mr. Aryce?. I have never talked to him since

a new plate hurts your gums. I went back but he seemed to think it was O.K. but I am going in again to-day as it sure makes me nervous. I have worn bifocals since I was 40 also. He told me to get Murine for an eye wash but that doesn't correct the glass. 
You have asked me a couple of times about a doughnut card but I don't believe I ever saw one.
I never hear a word about Mr. Payce. I have never talked to him since I left--

Siam" but weeked? out altho? some people liked it. I am going to-day to see "A Night in Paradise" and it had better be good. Friday I leave for my sister's and expect to be there two weeks. I that? they were to be gone a week but they have decided to stay longer. I am busy getting ready to leave and I sure hope it won't be raining. 
Looks like it this A.M. Well, I will have to say "Good-bye" for awhile so be good and you will be

Ganado, Arizona
September 2, 1946
Dear Mr. Burbank:
You once asked me to send you a picture
of myself so I found
this one taken the 
first spring I was 
here and am enclosing it.
The plum blossoms 
along the irrigation 
ditch were such
a pretty sight at
that time.

For about two weeks, an artist by the name of Ferdinand Burgdoff of Pebble Beach, California, has been at Sanado?, painting local scenes. He left here this morning. He painted some beautiful pictures of Indians with their horses and covered wagons, and a hogan and mesas His colors were very good and his cloud effects were splendid. I asked him if he had seen your pictures at Hubbells and he replied "I was here when he painted them." Saturday evening I saw La Charles at a reception for the graduate nurses here, and I told her that you had inquired about her. She said that she once

went to see you.
She has three boys and
they are very bright in school. 
No, I never met Anita
Thomas.
A new church was built 
here about five years ago.
It is built of stone and 
is a very nice place of worship.
I live at the Boys House
over the Dinning Hall.
I shall try  to get down
to Hubbell's to see Mrs.
Goodman some day soon
and look at your pictures again
Best wishes to you.

2
on paper Sisters of the Blessed Sacrament
St. michael's Indian School
St. Michaels, Arizona
been replaced with beautiful stone structures. There is a magnificent church which was donated by a New York Millioniare. The Fathers have a beautiful stone house too.
How pleased God must be with the way that you have given glory to Him by the use of the talents that He has given you.
School will open in a few days and you know that the Sisters always have plenty of work to do.
Hoping that you will continue to enjoy good health for many years and promising to remember you in my prayers, I am,
Sincerely yours,
Sister M. Honora

on paper Sisters of the Blessed Sacrament
St. Michael's Indian School
St. Michaels, Arizona
Sept. 1, 1946
Dear Mr. Burbank
Many, many thanks for the very welcome letter the small pictures, the beautiful picture suitable for framing of Abraham Lincoln and the book of Views of San Francisco.
Of course, the Entire? Bay Area was the most interesting picture in the whole book. San Francisco judging by the whole book must be a most beautiful city.
We are going to build a High School just as soon as we can get the materials.
Everything around the Mission in new (except Father Berard?) The old buildings have

Tuesday Evening
September 10, 1946
My Dear Elbridge
Just two days this week, and I have four letters from you each day. Really I do not deserve so much kindness from you when I do not have much time for writing. It is really wonderful to have a friend like you. You will never know how much I appreciate your kindness.
The Reader's Digest and The Family Circle both came today. Thank you so much for sending. This is a grand number of The Family Circle. It has so many good things in it. I really enjoy it.
This is also an exceptionally fine number of Reader's Digest. The article on Ernest Thompson Seton is very good. I did not know that he was still living, but I am certainly glad to know that he is.

I enjoy his books so much,
and I'm looking forward to his new book.
I am glad to have this article. In our literature book we study one of Seton's stories "Coaley?-Bay the Outlaw Horse." In the brief sketch about his life it says that he was the founder of the Boy Scouts. The scouts in class always say that Baden?-Powell was the founder. This article explains Setons part in the Boy Scout movement very well. I'm going to keep it to use, in class.
Did you tell me that you knew. Mr. Seton personally?
I have enjoyed the slippings. Thank you for the unclear for me.
We are having a much need rain here. The streams were drying up. Some near by taverns were having to ration drinking water unclear

night we had a hard electric storm, but the ground was so dry that it just absorbed all of the water.
You must have had quite a Labor Day celebration in San Francisco. The day was very quiet here without any celebrating.
I am returning Miss Erma Burbank's letter and picture. Thank you for sending it ti me to read.
Here it is getting late, and I have not had time for any thing but school. It is going very nicely so far, These warm days make one very tired. Perhaps the rain will cool things off some.
Lots of love,
Davie

Sept, 12-46
My dear Mr. Burbank:
Just before I left home I received too pictures from you One of an indian and one of the two cats, and I adore them both.
They are just lovely, and the one of the indian is perfect, you do such beautiful work; I will have them framed just as soon as I can.
I will enclose you ten dollars $10.00 for the pictures, the too you sent me.
I haven't been home for several days, as I had to come here and stay to take some from the doctor but I am going home tomorrow the 13th.
We will start to ship some of the cattle this coming saturday & sunday and I guess we will be shipping cattle off of our pastures for

the next two months. I will be very glad when the job is all over with, the cattle are looking just fine and have done exceptionally well this year they certainly are awfully fat.
Yes Mr. Burbank I live ina  very beautiful country, I do wish you were up here so you could paint some of this beautiful scenery, it is a lovely country.
Well Mr. Burbank I didn't get to finish my letter in the Falls, so I am home now and I received the lovely picture of that Tree in Santa unclear it is beautiful and I love it very much, I am enclosing you a money order for the three pictures, I will get them framed as soon as I go to town again.
Yes Mr & Mrs Baskins was here and I enjoyed having them

fine couple and I missed them very much when they left here?. they are down south now on a visit, visiting Mr. Baskins sister and are enjoying their visit very much, it was a pleasure having them both here with me.
Well Mr. Burbank how are you? I hope you are well & you take good care of your self.
I will see you when I come down this winter.
Give Mrs. Huff my love and tell her I will write to her just as soon as I get a itttle time.
We worked cattle & unclear some up unclear shipped them out yesterday, that was up at the marsh, we still have quite a few yet to ship out of

there, and then we will start shiping out here at Fort [Klamath] and and that will keep us busy for at least six weeks.  Well Mr Burbank I started this letter several days ago and have never been able to finish it.  we have been dreadfully busy. I hope this letter finds you well and happy.  With much love to you. I am always, Constance Dixon

I have never worked before in the business worked, but I find it delightful interesting.  I have made many lovely friends and talk to about a hundred people daily and I love people. [cut off] my work immensely.  We have [cut off]
Mr. Burbank; I am delighted with the lovely picture you have sent to me.  The work is exquisite and perfect.  You are a real honest-to-goodness artist.  and there are few souls who have been blessed with your marvellous talent.  You were sweet & dear to remember me in such a lovely way.  I shall frame & hang the picture where every day it will inspire me, and help me to remember the greatness in the heart of Lincoln, how precious is the memory of your friendship thru the years.  I have a very nice & dear husband & we are perfectly happy.  We are doing a great business here - have made $36,000 this year, & that is a lot of money for us - as we've never had that much before.  I keep the office here at the [Glorietta work] - make all the Rentals - keep books & cash drawer straight???? The best I can.

I have never worked before in the business world, but I find it delightful & interesting.  I have made many lovely friends & talk to about a hundred people daily and I love people so.  I enjoy my work immensely.  We have two maids & a gardner who do the hard work - so my Paul & I take it easy & roll in the money.  We love San Jose, it is a beautiful city - 140,000 population - fine stores & Theatres & the nicest most friendly people I've met since I left North Carolina.  Every one here is grand to us.  I've had a great deal published this year & have really finished a book I've been writing for four years. I hope it will be a best Seller.  I have done a great deal of oil painting this year also - I enjoy it very much, it is my hobby.  I sold a painting Xmas for $575.00, the most I ever got for one.  I still remember how lovely all the people at the [Manx] Hotel were to me & I shall never forget their many kind words & deeds - during my five years there.  My son Peter Watson, Manager of Mr. [Joy's} Hotel in Monterey has a lovely wife & a darling little son (Jimmy). [in paper fold] months old - & is the pride & joy of my heart.  Mr. [Joy] looks about ten years younger & happy & well - he has a very attractive & pretty wife!  May God bless your dear Mr. Burbank & grant you every wish of your heart in this near year & keep

Friday Night 
January 24, 1947
My Dear Elbridge,
The lovely birthday presents came today.
The book on California Missions is a lovely thing,
and I am so happy to have it, but I like the beautiful 
painting of the mission best because you made it. 
Thank you more than mere words can express.
You are such a good friend. The very best I ever had 
in all my life.
About two years ago you sent me a painting of another mission.

I will frame them and 
use them in a set.
These old missions
certainly look romantic. I
would love to visit one 
and see how it looks 
inside.
I will return your
letters in another envelope.
You mentioned the
hair ornament. It has 
not arrived yet, but
I'll wear it for you
when it comes.
I'am quite thrilled 
that you are sending
me one of the alcoline
shells that you painted.
I hope that it will
arrive safely and not get

3
broken. I knew that I will
like it. You have such
good taste, and select
such nice gifts. I like
every thing that you 
have ever sent me, but
I like most the things 
that you make for
me, I'm glad you painted the shell.
I havn't seen that
old sweetheart for two or 
three years. I see the
bachelor every few days.
His mother is up in
years, and is almost
helpless. He has to help
his sister to take care
for their Mother so he doesn't
go any place much except

4
to work. 
The magazine came 
today. It really does have
a lot of funny things in
it. I have gotten several 
good laughs.
From your letter it
seems to me that you are
doing an awful lot of work.
Now please don't over-
work again.
I do hope that
your room is more
comfortable, and that
you did not catch cold.
Thank you so much
for the mission picture
and book. I'm very anxious for my shell to come.
Lots of love,
Davie

Jan 30, 1947
My Dear Elbridge,
The [[unclear}} shell came last evening, and it is beautiful! Thank you very, very much. I like it so much. It is one the nicest things that you have given me. I put it on my living room table under the light and the colors were lovely! I like the light house scene that you painted on it. That is such an appropriate picture for the shell.

2
Pudgie likes the shell very much, and Andy thinks that it is so pretty.
I never knew that they grew so large. Where the holes are in the shell, I can put a ribbon and hang it up. For the present, however, I am going to leave it on my table
You are the grandest friend I have ever had in all my life. I appreciate all of the ovely things that you unclear

3
than I have words to tell you.
All of the things that you have sent have come except the the cards, and they will probably come today. I received the lovely Mission? picture, the Mission? book, athe clippers?, and the hair ornament. I like all of them very much. Big girls wear hair ornaments too.
Yesterday and the day before were just like spring. Today

4
a strong wind is blowing and I think that we are going to have a storm. I wish winter would come and stay for a few weeks. Every one would feel much better if is would.
My cold is much better if I can just keep it that way, but it is hard to dress for such changeable weather.
Thank you again very much for the lovely unclear shell, and all the lovely things.
With lots of love,
Davie?

3244 - Que St. N.W. 
Washington, D.C. Jan 13, 1946.
Dear Mr. Burbarnk: I don't know where you are living now but wherever you are drop me a line with this enclosed animal I have so much to tell you unclear some money also for you I want some painting unclear red? drawings. In haste I'll close til I get a letter from you dear. unclear unclear I sent best to you.
Sincerely 
Agnes Ruth HAWKINS
3244-Que St. N.W.

3460 Florida Ave
unclear, Calif.
Jan 10, 1947
My dear Mr. Burbank:
We recieved the painting, and the Lincoln prints, and must say that we are delightful beyond words. I wont be able to purchance any more of your fine works, and? am making it a point to show the painting to friends who are interested in Indians. unclear too when I get to Chicago, I shall certainly view? you out there. Again, never? I say, that we are well pleased with painting of the unclear.
Best regards,
Martin Cole?

3460 Florida Ave,
                             Riverside, Calif.
                             Dec 29. 1946.

Mr. E. A. Burbank,
Hotel Manx
San Francisco, Calf.
My dear Mr. Burbank:

                              The Caxton Printers have

advised me of your address. First I want to
mention my wife's and my appreciation for your
fine "Burbank Among the Indians." Recently
both of us have found ourselves becoming more
and more Indian conscience, and so it was with
the greater of interest, that we read of your
experiences.

                              However there was one

thing, that caught my fancy - I refer to
your sketch of "An Indian Stupa - or Meeting
Place, Isleta, N. M." you see, some twenty
years ago, when I was a young man just out
of college, I hitch hiked from the mid-west to
Calif. My hitch hiking thumb carried me to
Isleta, where darkness on this particular day over took me and made

it necessary that I spend the night with the
Indians. It was a day of ceremonies, and relay
races, so that night I was privledged to mount
the very same stone steps you have pictured, to
the top of the stupa and there mingle with two
score or more young Indian braves changing to
the obbligato of tom-toms. It was a night to
remember. That is why your picture of this
very same stupa caught my fancy and quickened
my pulse.

   Now then, would it be possible for me to

secure the original of this - what would be
your price - if it isn't for sale, then is
is there some way I could secure a copy,
large enough suitable for framing. Please
let me hear from you regarding this. I
shall await your reply. So until then,
Sincerely,
Martin Cole

Tuesday Night
January 28th, 1947
My Dear Elbridge,
Fine air mail letters came from you today and four yesterday. I really feel highly honored.
The hair ornament and the clippers came today. Thank you very much. The hair ornament is pretty and very unusual. I will wear it for you, and have my picture taken and send you one. There really isn't much good weather to take kodak? pictures in winter. The clippers are very good ones. Thank you for all of the cards and clippings. I always enjoy them.

2
The unclear shell has not came yet, but I am looking for it everyday. I am quite anxious to see it for I knew that it will be lovely.
The letters from the woman are rather unusual. I really don't know what to think about them. All of us have many troubles, but we are better off if we can forget them after they are past and gone. It doesn't make us or our friends any happier by talking about them.
You probably have my letter telling you that I received the book of the California Missions. I like it very much. It is a lovely thing.
Yes, I am very fond of oranges and I unclear unclear

3
plentiful right now. Sometimes we get oranges from California.
I do hope that the man can get the pictures or cards all in colors. That will be wonderful! I am anxious, especially to see the Lincoln one's in colors.
You are so good to me. The mission pictures are all lovely, but I have two mission pictures now and I don't have a cat picture that you have painted. I would love to have one of your cat paintings if that is all right with you. However if you would rather paint a mission, I like the "Mission Saw Carlos Barromeo? En? Monterey" very much.
Would the mission

4
that you sent me be pretty in a good frame? There is so much green in it, and I like green and gold together.
You can do the picture for my valentine. I have always loved the clever picture you drew of the wolf walking "3000 miles to Elkins? to see Davie." It was for my Valentine present once. Do you remember it? Everyone that sees it thinks that it is very clever.
Thank you very much for the two extra clippings about the unclear masks. I will send them to some of my Lincoln collector friends. It will be fine if Mr. Hamlin will publish the story, and see the Lincoln picture. I will

5
It is too bad that movies give you headache. I hadn't been to a movie for months until last week. I was given a free pass to see The unclear Picture.
Have you seen any of Dick's work since he has been going to art school?
One of Mrs. Shores' sisters is married but the youngest one isn't. She and Pudgie are about the same age. Yes, I knew her first husband.
Yes, I have read about Valk? making the mask of Lincoln, but I think that your part in it is most interesting. I have seen the masks in Washington too.
I am mailing one of the Lincoln cards to

6
Mr. Delkins tomorrow.
I am any thing but a good salesman. I just can't sell any thing.
My cold seems to be improving slowly. I do wish that it would hurry up and get well.
It will be fine if you and Mr. unclear get the unclear for your book.
Now I must say good night. Please take good care of yourself and do not work too hard. Thank you again for every thing.
With love,
Davie

196-16th Avenue
Greetings from Kilroy! Many thanks for your post cards. Clever and well done
Im putting them in my Burbank Collection. Your book was interesting and is a valuable resume of what is now History. So, Im delighted appreciation of "Burt Ink Aeuoug" unclear- Your Kilroy

Thursday Night
March 6, 1947
My Dear Elbridge,
It really doesn't look like this
ink is going to do very well on this
paper.
The calendar came today. You
are right. It is lovely. Thank you 
so much for it. Pudgie and Andy 
both think that is is beautiful too.
Today it had a letter from Mrs.
Paud that I had you make the 
cat painting for. Her birthday was
Feb, 26th. She certainly likes the 
picture. I sent her one of the
Calvin in the Hills too. She thinks 
is is beautiful, and so restful
and peaceful. She said anyone
could see that you liked cats.
She loves cats. She
says that you
are truly a great
artist. The sun has 
been shining today and 
same of the

snow is melting. My dad said 
that this is the deepest snow
that we have had since 1902. 
I only hope that it does not melt
off too fast, or we will have a big flood.
The streams are 
full already.
I have written Mrs. Paud so
much about you and how
good that you are to me. She
thinks that I'm a very lucky 
person to have such a grand 
friend as you, and I know
that I'm lucky.
There have been a lot of good
laughs in these recent funny
clippings that you have been
sending.
It is 11:30. I will write more later.
With my love,
Davie.

Sunday Night
February 9, 1947
My Dear Elbridge,
The laughing cat came last night, and it is grand! Thank you so much. I like it heaps. Pudgie and Andy like him too. I have him up here on a shelf in our dining room where we can see him all the time. My mission picture is up here too. I like to have it where I can look at it when I work. We have our coal stove here in the dining room, and here is where I work

of evenings.
The magazines came too. Thank you very much for them. This is a grand Arizona Highways. The flowers are lovely! It is a good number for information too.
Thank you too for the book on bridges. This one is different from the one you had sent me before. I am very glad to have it.
Miss Varscay, the girl friend, that you did the Lincoln picture for, was here today unclear

in Arizona and California. She liked my unclear shell, my cat picture and all of the things that you have sent me.
We are having cold snowy weather here for several days. It has been below zero for three days. I really can't get far from the stove.
These are such busy days that I havn't time for anything that I would like to do, but it just seems that I have to spend all of my time on my school

work.
Even if I do not write as often as I would like, please know that I think about you all the time.
With my love,
Davie
P.S. The Lincoln profile cards came. I will send the money for them in a day or two.

In the first place, every page of your experiences fascinated me because I have had from earliest childhood, a great romantic imagination about the Indians. Dewey once had a "crush" on an Indian boy who attended school with me where I was about 14 years old. (obviously nothing serious developed!) At any rate, Mr Burbank sure though I haven't time this morning to go into a move interesting dissentalism on both your book and an Indian - love I want to congratulate you on your superb artistry, as well as your excellent memory, your varied, colorful, unusual experiences.
I didn't realize before that

Fab. 25, 1947
Dear Mr. Burbank,
No doubt you are amazed to see my pecalian scriptt again so soon after my last letter! I really didn't expect to be writing, to be perfectly frank, but I did some unexpected reading during the last 2 days, and I want to write my reactions to you while they are so fresh.
From our Beverly Hills library, I unclear a copy of your book "Burbank Among the Indians" written with Ernest Royce, with exclusive Indian portraits by your own inimitable self. I was vey much impressed, Mr. Burbank, for now I know much more about you and unclear

-3-
You are one of those rare "young-old" men. In cleaner definition, though you are a man in your eighties, you will be forever young because of your love of God and nature and your sensitive yet sensible ideals. I only wish that I might have known you long ago- that you were of my generation!
Now Mr. Burbank, I shall conclude, for I do not wish to appear foolishly extravagant in my sencere praise. I do hope this finds you in excellent health and completely conteuted with your "many brushes."
Sincerely, as always,
Virginia Weekes
(Mrs. Don Weekes)

P.S. Just as I was going out the door, your last letter arrived, with its long, interesting account of Luther Burbank's History, etc. Thank you so much for your confidence. I do enjoy hearing from you very much.

My dear EAB,
I had better get busy and write some letters or I won't have any friends left. My! but those bridge books are swell and I thank you so much. I didn't realize how wonderful the bridges really are until I looked at the book. I am wondering where you were parked when you made that wonderful patch. It reminds me of your Mare Is. booklet. Somebody told me the M. I. booklets are on sale in unclear. I am sure my sister will appreciate the book you sent

for her. She may be over soon or I may go over there, so I will wait and give it to her then. I have enjoyed mine so very, very much. Isn't this weather sweet. Makes one almost feel young again. Every thing is so nice and green up here and how I like to be able to leave the doors open. Next thing we will be hollering it is too hot. This is Tuesday & we have an 11:00 am. show in town so I am going to-day to see "Humoresque." I am sure it will be good so Joan Crawford is in it. unclear

2/ lots better. When I had my glasses changed last year the oculist gave me some oily medicine to use in my eyes and I think that caused my trouble. I had dizzy spells and I decided to stop using it and I haven't been dizzy since. Medicine and I don't agree at all.
Aren't prices terrible. I wonder if that isn't what is the matter with my appetite. Could be.
I recieved your nice valentine (you sent me 2) and all the cards you sent me and I thank you very much.

I haven't seen Rod lately but then I haven't been to town so much lately. It sure is sweet having the little bus stop right at my door.
I heard on the radio that some man has made replicas of the cable cars and they are on sale at the Emporium. They must be quite tiny as you put them in a charm bracelet.
They gave the life history of Richard José on the radio a couple of months ago and I was wishing you could hear it.
Must get ready for town now so will say Good. bye.

Thursday Night
February 27, 1947
My Dear Elbridge,
What a grand lot of mail came from you today- two air mail letters, the lovely card, The Family Circle, The Pacific Rural Press and the package of lovely pictures.
Thank you for everything. You are so good to me. I wish that there were only some way that I could return all of your kindness to me.
I adore the card with the lovely verse. It really would be great to see you and have a nice long chat. This card will have a special place in my Burbank album.
The old St. Mary's church in China Town is pretty. Have you been to China Town lately?
The pictures are such good ones. I am going to let Pudgie have same

of them for her scrapbook on designs and ideas for handicraft and art.
This is one of the best copies of The Family Circle that you have sent me. There are a lot of things in it that I can see.
Andy was so pleased with his "Me-Worry" card. When I came? from school, he came running to the door to show it to me. He has it setting here on a shelf where he can show it to every one that comes.
Pudgie was very much pleased to have another letter from you. She said to tell you that she would answer soon.
Our snow storm is so severe here that we did not have school today, and will not have any tomorrow. It has snowed all day, and tonight it is quite cold. When you write of your Spring weather out there I can unclear imagine it.

be lovely and I am looking forward to its arrival.
Yes, I would like very much to have some of the covers of your book. Will you please autograph some of them for me? Some of my Lincoln collector friends to whom I have given the Lincoln print would like to have the cover I'm sure. I would like to have one for my Burbank scrapbook.
I expect a hot bath every day would be very weakening. I think that two or three hot tub baths a week in winter is enough. One can take spring baths other days.
There is always lots of work to do any time at school, but I'm hoping to have a few free evenings now to try and catch up with my letters.
You seem to have an swful lot of work to do. Now please do not over-work. Take good care

of yourself and stay well. You have always been such an abitious person. It makes me so happy to know that you are feeling good, and your friends say you look so well.
It is after 11:00 o'clock and I must get to bed.
Sweet dreams- I love you.
Davie

Feb-21, 1947
Dear Mr. Burbank,
You recent friendly letter was very welcome indeed and I am most happy to send you the postcard as requested. It is the least I can do to repay you for your postcards and the Lincoln print. If you care for an assortment of scenic pictures from this area I shall gladly send some.
Mr. Burbank, I want you to know most sincerely, that I consider you a very great artist. I think your portraits of unclear unclear especially, Lincoln, T. Roosevelt,and Will Rogers are the best I've ever seen- and although I'm quite a young person, I've seen a great many. I admire your work so very much and I would like to own many more samples of it. However, I must confess that my husband and I are just getting on out feet and

-2-
we cannot allow ourselves any undue luxuries. Only a year ago, he returned from the service, and due to ill health and family responsibilities combined, we decided to come out here The climate has already improved our health- but- it is a long, hard struggle to achieve one's ambitions in this crowded area. We don't ever have very private living quaters. We'll just have to square our soldiers and keep lighting every minute. However, we aren't complaining. We're very much in love, and even of? our very worst times; we're still 100% better off than the miserable people of Europe! So Mr. Burbank, I still hope someday- not too far away- that we will reach our goal and be able to afford your book and more pictures! We'll be very proud to own them. Be sure and save us some.
Always sincerely,
Virginia Weekes

115N, Almansor, Alhambran
March 14, 47,
My dear Faithful Friend, Thanks for your good letter and the cards, glad to know you keep well and happily busy I am fairly well and get around some on my crutches I read my eyes are good and I knit making knee covering for wounded lads in Hospital

Our Luotsie? Johnson is now at Second Mesa among our beloved Indians and is she Happy! the days are so lovely and the flowers are so beautiful life seems pleasant in spite all the unrest of hate and sin and selfishness, there is lots of kindness and helpfulness in spite of it all, I wonder if you get out into the country sometimes to see the green fields and wild flowers and the fruit trees in bloom and have a picknic and enjoy eating out doors. faithfully with kind regards, S E Abbott

4/1/47
Mr. E A Burbank
San Francisco
Dear Mr. Burbank,
I am sorry that you have not been paid for your book. I saw Charles Sunday the 23rd and I understood him to say he would attend to the matter
However I'm enclosing a check for the amount and wish to say that I have enjoyed reading it.
Very truly
unclear

Tuesday
April 29, 1947
My Dear Elbridge,
I have a few minutes here at school so thought that I would at least begin your letter.
Yesterday there were four letters and an envelope of clipping all from you. Andy and I enjoyed the clippings. He brought your letters to me and said, "Open them, Aunt Davie, and see if there are any for me." You are spoiling him. His Lincoln print has not come yet. Saturday he got the baby picture in the mailing tube?. How fine of you to send him a Lincoln print. His Mother

2
will keep it for him until he is old enough to appreciate it. He knows Mr. Lincoln any place that he sees his picture.
I do hope that you will be able to get one of the magazines with your picture and the article. I will send you the 25¢ for it.
Sometime ago you said that you would send me a copy of The Pony Express with your drawing of the "Owl." I hope that it did not get last in the mail if you sent it.
How are you feeling now? In one of your letters you said that you were not feeling so

3
so hard, and get plenty of sleep and rest. You are too ambitious for your own good.
We had quite a hard frost Sunday night. I fear that our fruit has been killed again. The weather continues to stay chilly in spite of the sun shine.
All nature is really getting lovely in our hills. The various shades of green are a delight to the eyes. We have a wide variety of trees, and the leaves are so many shades of green in spring.
I sent Mrs. Shore a note and inquired if she were ill as I had not heard from her since in February. I will write you when I hear

4
from her.
This next month of school will be gone before we know it. I have really enjoyed school this winter more than usual. That is because I have felt better, and I am so glad. It is terrible to try to work when one is not feeling well.
We certainly have written often to each other. In fact I have been neglecting all of my friends except the letters that I write to you.
Please take good care of yourself, and stay well.
With Love, Davie

Wednesday Night
April 16, 1947
My Dear Elbridge,
These are such busy days, and will continue to be busy ones from now until school closes. It is now 10:30. I have spent all evening grading papers, and still have a large stack to grade. We have been having warm days here too, but tonight is much cooler. There is a cold wind blowing. I do hope that we will not have more snow now that spring flowers are blooming.
Days have been so warm that I have had spring fever or something. I am so tired when I come home of evenings that sometimes I have had to lie down and rest unclear as I got home.
Andy and I have both

2
enjoyed the many clippings that you have sent us. Yes, Andy has a scrap book, He and his Mother have been working on it.
Thank you very much for the Lincoln clippings. The one on April 14th is a most interesting one. I am also glad to have the one with Governor Green of Illinois. The people out there say that he has made Illinois an excellent governor.
The Desert Magazine has not come, but I'm looking forward to getting it. You sent the copy with the fine article about you in it. I like it very much.
Thank you for the paper telling about the Easter Services. They must be very lovely. I had a letter from

3
going through the Panama Canal when he wrote it. He did not know when he would be in San Francisco again, but he said that he would call to see you again when he is Yes. the cartoon about perfume and fried chicken is very clever. Pudgie and I had a good laugh over it.
It is late and I must take a bath and get to bed.
Please take good care of yourself and do no work too hard. 
Sweet dreams!
With love, 
Davie

Monday Night
St Patrick's Day 1947
My Dear Elbridge,
My, what a lot of grand mail came from you today. First the lovely shamrock. I got my mail when I came home at noon so I put the shamrock right on my dress and wore it back to school. Every one thought that it was lovely. It is the prettiest one I ever saw. I have put it back on the card, and will keep it always with my Burbank treasures.
There were four air mail letters and an envelope of clippings two Pony Express, The Pacific Rural Press, News Week, and the package of fine clippings. Thank you so much for every thing. You are so good to me.
Your picture Portal of the Past in the Pony Express is lovely! When I showed it to Pudgie she said,

that is a photograph." I said, "Yes, but a photograph of Mr. Burbank's picture." The original must be perfect. I really can't see how you do such fine work.
Pudgie and Andy both have the "flu", and I have all of the work to do and wait on them. I scarcely knew if I were going to coming Saturday and Sunday. Today I went to school, but I rushed right home and have been very busy- just sat down to read my mail at 9:30.
Andy just loves to get mail. Yes, his Mother will let him open the dog painting when it comes. He always opens all of his own mail. I let him help me open packages too. He always gets so much fun from doing it. It is very kind and unclear unclear

a picture for him. How like you to do the good, kind things. He will frame it for his room. He loves the cards and clippings that you send him. Thank you for them. Andy recognizes the letters that come from you.
Yes, I would like very much to have some more of the covers of your book. So many people that I send the prints want to know about you
It is 10:30, and I must see about my sick people, and get to bed as I have to get up early to get things ready for them in the morning. Thank you again for everything. You are such a grand friend. I am inclosing one dollar for the four ship and airplane pictures.

will send the other seventy-five cents later. 
Please take good care of yourself and do not get this awful "flu"
Good night and sweet dreams.
My love,
Davie
P.S. I adore the card that came from you Saturday "I would be tickled pink--".

Thursday Night
April 10, 1947
My Dear Elbridge,
Thank you so much for the pretty Florida Souvenir. It will make a pretty lapel pin. It is different from any thing that I have ever seen. I like it, and I'll wear it tomorrow.
The tin "Can You Loan Me A Dollar" cards came. I'm inclosing fifty cents for them. You certainly did a grand job on the old man. Everyone that sees it likes it.
I wish that you could hear all of the wonderful things that people say about my Lincoln picture. It is wonderful! How proud I am to have it.
I have not heard from Mrs. Shore for several weeks. I think that I will send her a card. I am afraid that she

has been sick.
Are you having past card size pictures made of "My Cabin in the Hills?" I am glad if you enjoy my letters. You write me so often, and such interesting letters. I never have anything much of interest to write to you.
The dog drawing in colors must have been very pretty. How I wish that I could see all of your pictures!
Thank you for The Pacific Rural Press and all of the clippings! Andy enjoys the unclear you send for him. he liked "Their New Master" card that you sent him.
With lots of love,
Davie

214 Diamond Street
Elkins, West Virginia
Mar. 14, 1947
My Dear Elbridge,
I have had so many things to do this week that I haven't gotten any letters written except yours. From now on until school is out we will be having a lot of extra things to do.
We has rain last night, and it is still raining today. Quite a lot of our snow has gone off, and the streams are full of water. I hope that we will not have a flood.
I am at school now- 8:00, and I can hear a bird singing outside my window? unclear unclear

2
can't be very far away for March is half gone. I am very glad
Your letter from Mr. Kilroy's niece is a very interesting one. Your friend Mr. Kilroy must be a very fine person. I think that I would like to see and know them both.
The Pony Express with your drawing of "The Portals of the Past" has not come yet. I am quite anxious to see it
I am glad that this is Friday for I feel like I am taking a cold. Pudgie is getting one too. So many of my pupils have colds. There is a lot of "flu"is many sections

3
of our stale, and in many other states too. I do hope that we will not get it here.
You must be careful and stay well. The best way to stay well is to get plenty of rest and not over-work.
What kind of new suit did you get? What color? I know that you must look fine in it.
I really need a lot of new clothes. I bought only the things I already needed driving the unclear, and now they are all worn out. The high cost of living doesn't leave one much money for clothes.

4
Our state wanted to raise our salaries for next year. We are so glad for we really do need it.
I do not have your letters here so I do not remember what questions you ask.
The letter from Mr Kilroy's niece I am returning by regular mail. It would take me cents to send it air mail. I hope that it wil reach you in good condition.
Do not work too hard.
With love,
Davie

Dear Mr. Burbank:- I have been very remiss in my thanks to you for your mail etc. The Geronimo sketch arrived in good shape and is muchly appreciated.
I hope you remember that I have already paid for this- I know it was so long ago it could be easily forgotten.
I hope to be in S.F. during May. I gave the things to my sister and she was very pleased.
Best regards,
Nina Joss?
March 22nd

Dear Mr. Burbank:
Giving me such a marvelous painting has flattered me very much.
Even I, a layman, can see that it is of superb artistry.
I give you my very sincerest and warmest thanks in return, Sharon Doolle?

"flu'. I think that I have just been working too hard, and need to rest.
I hope that you have received Mr. Kilroy's niece's letter.I sent it last week by regular mail. It should be there by now.
The clipping have furnished me with several good laughs. I always enjoy them a lot. It is so thoughtful of you to take all of the time for me.
Your new clothes must look fine. How I wish that I could see you.
Probably the lady in Washington has the "flu" or can't afford to get any more pictures now.
I must close and see about sick people and get some rest.
Goodnight- sweet dreams.
With love,
Davie

my niece a brunette was lovely in her lovely white satin gown. The brides maids were all so pretty in their long gowns of pastel shades of green, blue, and yellow
I have corresponded with Mrs. Paud? for some time, but I had never met her personally until I went to Petersburg, Illinois last sumer. She and her husband are two of the grandest people that I have ever known any place. They are both such good, intellectual people. If we had more people like that the Pands? and your own dear self what a grand world this would be.
The true story that you write is a very interesting one. It reads just like a book.
Good unclear

P.S. My nephew wrote his home folks that he had enjoyed his visit with you. He said that you looked to be about sixty-five years old. How do you keep looking so young? It must be because you keep working, and have so many interests in life.

Wednesday Night
March 19, 1947
My Dear Elbridge,
You certainly made our Andy a happy little boy today. He knows his card a dog painting. I wish that you could have seen him opening the package. He had to take his dog painting to bed with him tonight. He said "Tell Mr. Burbank 'thank you'. He is an awful nice man." Pudgie and I both think the dog is grand. We like him every bit as much as Andy.
Today brought a lot of nice mail from you for me too. There were three air mail letters, the Popular Mechanic Magazine, the very pretty view cards, the lovely Easter card and an envelope of clippings. Thank you so much for every thing. How do you find time to do so many nice things unclear unclear and

all of your other friends? I hope that all of the others appreciate your wonderful kindness as much as I do. Oh, I'm so glad that you will do the Lincoln drawing for me. You are so good to do it for me at that price. No girl in all the world ever had such a wonderful friend and you have been to me.
Pudgie and Andy are a little better. They have sat up a little today. I just hope that they will continue to improve. When any of my family are sick, it worries me so I can't sleep or rest.
Today has been a pretty day. My calendar says that Spring is day after tomorrow. I will be very glad when it gets here.
I feel so tired tonight. I

214 Diamond Street
Elkins, West Virginia
April 1, 1947
My Dear Elbridge
The Lincoln drawing came today, and it is wonderful! I believe that this is the very best drawing of all. I love it.
I got the slip that the package was at the office so I sent two of my pupils up for it. So I had it at school all day, and showed it to my pupils. I wish that you could have heard all the wonderful things that they said about it. Some of them could not believe that it is a pencil drawing. The teachers all liked it too.
I wish that I could find words to tell you how very, very much I like the picture.
The picture of the dog and

it very much too. Andy liked it so much too.
Thank you for the magazine and clippings. The Pacific Rural Press, The Pony Express, and the small magazine. How nice of you to send them all. Oh, yes, the grand copy of The Arizona Highways came this evening too.
The clippings about Lincoln and Justice Holmes is a very interesting one. I am so glad to have it for my Lincoln scrapbooks. I have heard this story about Lincoln but had never read it.
Yes, I would like to unclear a half dozen of "My Cabin in the Hills." I like to give them to my friends for gifts. Everyone likes them so much.
One of my nieces was married today. She had a large church unclear

March 22, 1947
My dear EAB
Well, I am home again and found quite a few clippings and letter from you. I enjoy all the cards and slippings you send me and thank you for them.
I don't think I am so well as I don't seem to want to do anything but just sit around. I didn't stay very long at my sister's as I expect to go back in a month or two to take care of the cat while they go to L.A.
I haven't seen any

unclear lately. They have discontinued the Tuesday A.M. I have? in Napa? but can go in the P.M. The unclear Stary? is here more and I don't know whether to go this P.M. or not.
I am not eating so well lately but we have a Chinese restaurant in town and I do enjoy their food- they surely know how to cook nice. It has been in Napa? for years but I never thought I would like it.
Did you get a chance to hear the Luiher? Burbank programs. I listened &

2/ the part. Did you know he is quite an artist. My sister has an etching he did of a water scene.
We never had very gloomy weather and I think a little sunshine would do all of us a lot of good.
They said on the Radio yesterday that they expect Easter to be a nice sunny day so we had better get our Easter bonnets ready.
I gave my sister the bridge book you send her and she was so pleased

with it, especially your drawing. and asked me to thank you very much.
I haven't made any dolls since before Xmas. I have no way of selling them. The money helped a lot and I miss it. I know I made over 200 of them.
Must get to work now so will send this along with the card I forgot to mail.
N.

[[On paper- Diamond Tail Ranch
Howard Flitner
Greybull, Wyoming]]
March 4-1947
My dear Mr. Burbank,
I am the neice of George Kilroy hwo was in San Francisco late in January. My husband and I should have found time for a visit with you, unclear you fabulous city unclear us on a continuous merry-90-round for the week we were there. What a wonderful city it is! We do enjoy is so much when we return- The only trouble being that we cannot get there often enough.
Thank you very much for the two unclear of Lincoln you sent to us. It is a very striking pose, serious, unclear still Lincoln has a little whimsical expression about his eyes which many artists make so serious and sombre. I have one copy to a very dear friend of mine on Lincoln's Birthday. She was delighted with it and sent it to Billings unclear or once to be framed.
We were happy to have your book "Burbank among the Indians" to add to our Library. It? is a beautifully

[[On paper- Daimond Tail Ranch
Howard Flitner
Greybull, Wyoming]]
done work, and much more important to us now that we have met you by proxy.
We are having a little more snow today- We had wonderful sunny warm days until late February and since then it has again turned cold; however we can expect this weather sometimes and it may as well be now as later when when we are unclear and uncear on the ranch. We will be shearing? next week so we are hoping for a quick change in weather before then. This begins our very interesting time on the ranch someday I hope to unclear a tale about it all, unclear & am so busy with my four lively youngsters now there is a little time for story writing?- and besides I can tell wonderfully interesting Ranch tales, unclear getting? them down on paper is something else again.
Hope this finds you well- Uncle George says you arise early in the mornings- you and my husband would agree- he loves to get  up early. We did so enjoy our visit with Uncle George- He is a very interesting man- always has been My unclearr unclear unclear unclear unclear only unclear

Something or tell it over the Radio. I'm sure he could do wonders - Wish I had time to be his Manager?!
Thank you again for being so generous with your Lincolns and I do hope that when we are again in San Francisco we shall meet.
Very Sincerely -
unclear Desmond Zlituer
(Mis Howard)

Sunday Night
Dear Mr. Burbank:
Easter has come and gone and I am at last getting a little caught up with my work. The days are so pretty and sunny- just right for washing and cleaning. 
We have been to two lovely Spring weddings these two weeks- one, my neices' and the other, a good friend.
My, those white satin dresses were lovely an dthe flowers and music were too. Andy

was quite thrilled at all the sights and beloved? times. He surely? gets a big unslear and? of opening the things you send unclear. He is so thrilled when there is mail for unclear. We all liked the picture of the bean?, and the chinese cards, but still think the little yellow puppy is the unclear of all. Andy? and I are making a scrap book of the cards and pictures and things you send unclear. unclear

one surely lucky that you don't have to be bothered with cleaning, and things like that.
We are making things of tin in my art & Handi craft class, now. We make candle holders, and trays, by hammering? the tin and then punching the design with a nail. Then the whole thing is polished with steel wool and the finished product looks like hammered silver. Next week, we are making animals of newspaper and a mache? mixture of paper strips and glue.
As an artist, Mr. Burbank,

you would probably get a great laugh out of some of our attempts to create beauty from common things, but it does help a lot in rural school teaching.
Mr. Burbank, could you tell me about how the Indians baked their pottery in outside kilns, and if I could set up anything similiar here in West Virginia? And I would like to know about the paint and unclear they used. If possible, I would like for my school children to

Everyone enjoys looking at them, and just last week our church society was studying about China, so Davie and I gathered up our chinese things you had sent us, and displayed them. Everyone was very interested, especially the chinese candy- although there was only two pieces of candied ginger and some of the unclear sound? fruit left. I also had some of the jasmine tea- to look at. One of these days, I'll send some money and love you to send me some more.
By-the-way, the people's

name you gave me to write to, never did answer so probably they don't have the beads. I am making earring of sequins and seed beads, and I'm afraid I'll run out before long.
How have you been feeling this nice, spring weather? I'll bet you find it hard to stay inside and paint. I don't know whether Andy and I will get much work done or not! Anyway, I believe the walks in the sun will do Andy more good than cleaning unclear unclear unclear

for the nice things you send Andy and me. With all your work I don't see how you find time to do such nice things for people.
This is a long letter, so I will close for this time. I hope you are feeling fine, and enjoying the pretty weather.
We are looking forward to hearing from you, and of course Davie is, too. She doesn't feel so well, but? will try her best to finish school out.
Write again soon.
Your West Va. friends,
Pudgie and Andy

815  unclear unclear. Antrich? Calif unclear 14
47?
My dear cousin Elbridge.
I feel ashamed that I have not written you before thanking? for the nice cards you have sent us. Hope you are feeling well this weather?. As you know I have been in unclear condition since any unclear back east last summer. I'm on the move now but still unclear unclear unclear digital's & unclear unclear hills. I think it is wonderful how unclear unclear so well and unclear. My sister Amy is in a unclear home

unclear is working too hard unclear did not look very well last week.
in Somerville? unclear. is in better health and spirits now than  for sometime
She has eye trouble and her unclear is failing somewhat. She is well taken care of and she may gain? enough to so some painting later.
Hope the book is still selling well it certainly ought to
unclear Regards
unclear Couson? R.S. Burbank
